courses.title: Network Models
courses.longTitle: OSI and TCP IP Network Models
courses.description: My deep, practical guide to how network communication works, using OSI and TCP IP as mental models you can actually apply for troubleshooting and security.

levels.title: OSI and TCP IP Foundations
levels.label: Foundations
levels.summary: Encapsulation, addressing, and the purpose of layers, explained with exact terms and safe labs.
learning_outcomes: Explain what a protocol is and what a network model is, using precise definitions.
Explain encapsulation and decapsulation using correct protocol data unit names.
Map OSI layers to TCP IP layers and explain what the mapping does and does not mean.
Describe how DNS, HTTP, and HTTPS fit into a real request flow.
Use browser and command line inspection to observe DNS, TLS, and HTTP behaviour safely.

levels.title: Applied OSI and TCP IP
levels.label: Applied
levels.summary: Layer by layer behaviour with TCP, UDP, routing, NAT, and TLS, with realistic troubleshooting.
learning_outcomes: Explain how TCP provides reliability and what reliability means in measurable terms.
Explain UDP trade offs and name common protocols that use it and why.
Explain what routing is and how IP forwarding differs from switching.
Explain what NAT changes and what it does not change, with common failure modes.
Use a structured troubleshooting method to isolate a fault to a layer and prove it.

levels.title: Network Models for Security and Operations
levels.label: Practice & Strategy
levels.summary: Security, monitoring, and operations thinking built on correct network foundations, without unsafe attacking.
learning_outcomes: Explain how common security failures map onto layers and where controls actually apply.
Design a minimal logging and monitoring plan for a web service using layer aware signals.
Explain how to reason about packet captures without turning learning into exploitation.
Describe common enterprise controls such as segmentation, least privilege network access, and secure DNS.
Produce a defensible network troubleshooting write up with evidence and clear assumptions.

bands.label: Foundations
bands.title: OSI and TCP IP Foundations
bands.summary: Encapsulation, addressing, and the purpose of layers, explained with exact terms and safe labs.

bands.label: Intermediate
bands.title: Applied OSI and TCP IP
bands.summary: Layer by layer behaviour with TCP, UDP, routing, NAT, and TLS, with realistic troubleshooting.

bands.label: Advanced
bands.title: Network Models for Security and Operations
bands.summary: Security, monitoring, and operations thinking built on correct network foundations, without unsafe attacking.

courses.title: Cybersecurity
courses.description: My three level cybersecurity course that takes learners from basic online safety to professional risk and security practice, using interactive tools and everyday examples.

levels.title: Cybersecurity Foundations
levels.label: Foundations
levels.summary: Friendly on-ramp for data, networks, passwords, phishing and everyday defences using in-browser labs.
learning_outcomes: Explain what data, bits, bytes and encodings are and why small changes in data matter for security.
Describe the CIA triad of confidentiality, integrity and availability in simple language with everyday examples.
Recognise in plain terms how information moves between devices and across networks at a high level.
Explain what a trust boundary and attack surface are, with simple examples from home and work life.
Use the hashing and encoding tools to see how small changes in input create large changes in output and relate this to integrity.
Use the password and URL tools to judge the strength of passwords and the safety of basic links or emails.
Describe preventive, detective and corrective controls and give examples of each.
Record simple risks and controls in a risk matrix and justify chosen likelihood and impact in plain terms.

levels.title: Applied Cybersecurity
levels.label: Applied
levels.summary: Think like attackers and defenders with threat modelling, web auth flows, common vulns, logs, and risk trade-offs.
learning_outcomes: Apply basic threat modelling to simple systems, identifying assets, actors, entry points and likely threats.
Explain the role of operating systems, networks and services in security and relate them to the OSI and TCP IP models.
Describe common classes of vulnerabilities such as injection, broken authentication and insecure configuration.
Explain how authentication, authorisation, sessions and cookies work together in a web application.
Interpret simple logs and alerts, linking them back to potential misuse or attacks.
Use risk matrices and control catalogues to justify security trade offs in realistic scenarios.

levels.title: Cybersecurity Practice and Strategy
levels.label: Practice & Strategy
levels.summary: Join up governance, secure design, DevSecOps, CVEs, incident response and business-focused risk thinking.
learning_outcomes: Relate enterprise security decisions to formal frameworks such as CISSP domains and NIST CSF 2.0 functions.
Explain how Cyber Essentials Plus style controls map onto layered technical and organisational defences.
Design high level secure architectures for small web or cloud based systems, including identity, logging and monitoring.
Use vulnerability information such as CVEs to prioritise remediation work in a structured way.
Outline a simple incident response approach from detection to recovery and lessons learned.
Communicate key security risks and mitigations to non technical stakeholders in clear, concise language.

bands.label: Foundations
bands.title: Cybersecurity Foundations
bands.summary: Friendly on-ramp for data, networks, passwords, phishing and everyday defences using in-browser labs.

bands.label: Intermediate
bands.title: Applied Cybersecurity
bands.summary: Think like attackers and defenders with threat modelling, web auth flows, common vulns, logs, and risk trade-offs.

bands.label: Advanced
bands.title: Cybersecurity Practice and Strategy
bands.summary: Join up governance, secure design, DevSecOps, CVEs, incident response and business-focused risk thinking.

courses.title: AI
courses.description: From what data is and how simple models work through to deep learning, transformers, agents and real world AI systems.

levels.title: AI Foundations
levels.summary: Start from data, simple models, and how to read accuracy and bias without drowning in maths.
learningOutcomes: Explain what data is and the difference between features, labels, inputs and outputs.
Describe in plain language what supervised and unsupervised learning are trying to do.
Understand basic ideas like training, validation and testing at a high level.
Recognise common data problems such as bias, noise and leakage.

levels.title: Applied AI
levels.summary: Work with evaluation, features, embeddings, and practical model use without the buzzword fog.
learningOutcomes: Describe how common model families such as linear models, trees and simple neural networks behave.
Explain important evaluation metrics in context, such as accuracy, precision, recall and F1, and when they are appropriate.
Connect data preparation, feature engineering and model training as one pipeline rather than isolated steps.
Relate model choices and trade offs to real business or policy questions.

levels.title: Modern AI Systems
levels.summary: Transformers, agents, diffusion models, and how real AI systems are designed, governed, and sometimes misused.
learningOutcomes: Explain at a high level how transformer based models, agents and diffusion models work and where they fit.
Discuss AI risks such as bias, safety and misuse in concrete scenarios, not only in abstract terms.
Connect AI system design to governance, regulation and organisational guardrails.
Describe a realistic lifecycle for building, deploying, monitoring and improving AI systems in practice.

bands.label: Foundations
bands.title: AI Foundations
bands.summary: Start from data, simple models, and how to read accuracy and bias without drowning in maths.

bands.label: Intermediate
bands.title: Applied AI
bands.summary: Work with evaluation, features, embeddings, and practical model use without the buzzword fog.

bands.label: Advanced
bands.title: Modern AI Systems
bands.summary: Transformers, agents, diffusion models, and how real AI systems are designed, governed, and sometimes misused.

courses.title: Software Architecture
courses.description: From basic diagrams and responsibilities through to microservices, events, CQRS, cloud native systems and digitalisation architecture.

levels.title: Architecture Foundations
levels.summary: Start from what architecture is for, and how to think about components, boundaries and responsibilities in small systems.
learningOutcomes: Explain in simple terms what software architecture is and why it matters.
Describe basic building blocks such as components, interfaces and data flows.
Read and sketch simple architecture diagrams such as layered and client server views.
Relate architecture decisions to non functional needs such as performance, security and reliability.

levels.title: Applied Architecture
levels.summary: Layered patterns, microservices, events, data ownership and real trade offs between coupling, performance and changeability.
learningOutcomes: Describe and compare common architectural styles such as layered systems, microservices and event driven designs.
Explain key runtime qualities such as scalability, resilience and maintainability with concrete examples.
Use simple patterns such as CQRS, event sourcing and message queues in realistic scenarios.
Discuss trade offs between different designs for a given problem.

levels.title: Digital and Cloud Scale Architecture
levels.summary: Event driven systems, CQRS, integration patterns, observability and digitalisation strategy across whole organisations.
learningOutcomes: Connect architecture work to digitalisation strategy, organisational change and long term evolution of systems.
Explain how architecture governance, roadmaps and standards guide delivery teams without blocking them.
Reason about architecture in regulated and safety critical contexts in plain language.
Describe a realistic end to end path from idea to production for complex digital systems.

bands.label: Foundations
bands.title: Architecture Foundations
bands.summary: Start from what architecture is for, and how to think about components, boundaries and responsibilities in small systems.

bands.label: Intermediate
bands.title: Applied Architecture
bands.summary: Layered patterns, microservices, events, data ownership and real trade offs between coupling, performance and changeability.

bands.label: Advanced
bands.title: Digital and Cloud Scale Architecture
bands.summary: Event driven systems, CQRS, integration patterns, observability and digitalisation strategy across whole organisations.

courses.title: Data
courses.description: A practical and rigorous course on data, from formats and models to governance, architecture, and real-world use across AI, cybersecurity, and digital systems.

levels.title: Data Foundations
levels.summary: Start with the language, formats, and habits that make data useful across teams.
learningOutcomes: Explain why data matters to outcomes and how roles collaborate.
Recognise common data formats and how they shape modelling choices.
Describe simple storage and querying approaches.
Discuss data quality, stewardship, and responsible use at a basic level.

levels.title: Applied Data
levels.summary: Move into models, pipelines, and applied analytics while keeping reliability in view.
learningOutcomes: Outline schemas that fit real questions and constraints.
Sketch pipeline steps from ingestion to integration.
Connect analytics and feature shaping to downstream uses like AI and reporting.
Plan for tests, monitoring, and trust signals in data flows.

levels.title: Advanced Data Systems
levels.summary: Join up data architecture, streaming, governance, and product thinking for real systems.
learningOutcomes: Compare warehouse and lakehouse approaches at a high level.
Describe how streaming and real time needs influence design.
Relate governance and stewardship models to scaling teams.
Explain how data products keep ownership and interfaces clear.

bands.label: Foundations
bands.title: Data Foundations
bands.summary: Start with the language, formats, and habits that make data useful across teams.

bands.label: Intermediate
bands.title: Applied Data
bands.summary: Move into models, pipelines, and applied analytics while keeping reliability in view.

bands.label: Advanced
bands.title: Advanced Data Systems
bands.summary: Join up data architecture, streaming, governance, and product thinking for real systems.

courses.title: Digitalisation
courses.description: From basic concepts about data and processes through to digital operating models, platforms, governance and strategy.

levels.title: Digitalisation Foundations
levels.summary: Start with what digitalisation actually means, how data, people, processes and systems fit together, and how to read basic diagrams and operating models.
learningOutcomes: Explain what digitalisation is in plain language and how it differs from simple digitisation and automation.
Describe how data, processes and people fit together in a digital operating model.
Recognise common digital building blocks such as APIs, platforms and self service portals.
Relate digitalisation to basic ideas like value, customer journeys and system outcomes.

levels.title: Applied Digitalisation
levels.summary: Move into platforms, integration, data sharing, capabilities, and how organisations design digital journeys and services in practice.
learningOutcomes: Describe how digitalisation changes the way organisations plan, build and operate services.
Explain the role of data platforms, integration patterns and standards in a digital ecosystem.
Discuss real trade offs between speed, quality, risk and regulatory duties in digital projects.
Map simple end to end journeys and identify where digital changes can improve outcomes.

levels.title: Digital Strategy and Enterprise Scale
levels.summary: Look at digital roadmaps, operating models, governance, regulation and how to align data, architecture and people at sector or enterprise scale.
learningOutcomes: Connect digitalisation work to strategy, policy and long term investment decisions.
Explain how governance, architecture and product thinking support sustainable digital change.
Discuss how to measure digital outcomes using meaningful metrics rather than vanity numbers.
Describe real world challenges such as legacy systems, skills, regulation and vendor lock in, and how to work with them.

bands.label: Foundations
bands.title: Digitalisation Foundations
bands.summary: Start with what digitalisation actually means, how data, people, processes and systems fit together, and how to read basic diagrams and operating models.

bands.label: Intermediate
bands.title: Applied Digitalisation
bands.summary: Move into platforms, integration, data sharing, capabilities, and how organisations design digital journeys and services in practice.

bands.label: Advanced
bands.title: Digital Strategy and Enterprise Scale
bands.summary: Look at digital roadmaps, operating models, governance, regulation and how to align data, architecture and people at sector or enterprise scale.
